section.title: Blinking LED.
section.para: This example shows the simplest thing you can do with an Arduino to see physical output: it blinks a LED.

section.title: Circuit.
section.para: To build the circuit, attach a 220-ohm resistor to pin 13.
Then attach the long leg of an LED (the positive leg, called the anode) to the resistor.
Attach the short leg (the negative leg, called the cathode) to ground.
Then plug your Arduino board into your computer, start the Arduino program, and load and run the code.
Most Arduino boards already have an LED attached to pin 13 on the board itself.
If you run this example with no hardware attached, you should see that LED blink. .
